facts.text: Kirpal Singh and his two brothers Arjun Singh and Sarwan Singh were tried by the Sessions Judge, Pillibhit for causing the death of Karam Singh with gunshot injuries in the evening of March 26, 1961 at Village Shanti Nagar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Kirpal Singh and his two brothers Arjun -Singh and Sarwan Singh, were tried by the Sessions judge, Pillibhit for causing the death of one Karam Singh with gunshot injuries in the evening of March 26, 1961 at Village Shanti Nagar.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted Arjun Singh and Sarwan Singh and convicted Kirpal Singh of the offence and sentenced him to death subject to confirmation by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions judge acquitted Arjun Singh and Sarwan Singh and convicted the appellant Kirpal Singh of the offence charged against him and sentenced him to suffer the penalty of death subject to confirmation by the High Court.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court confirmed the conviction and sentence of Kirpal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Allahabad confirmed the order of conviction and sentence.

facts.text: Kirpal Singh appealed to the Supreme Court by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1962 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 877 of 1962 and Referred No. 79 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 54 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1962, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 877 of 1962 and Referred No. 79 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant Kirpal Singh and his father-in-law Rakkha Singh were refugees from West Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his father-in-law Rakkha Singh were refugees from West Pakistan.

facts.text: A block of agricultural land allotted by the Government to Rakkha Singh and the appellant was partitioned but no boundary marks were erected on the line dividing the lands.

anchor.surface_text: A block of agricultural land, allotted by the Government to Rakkha Singh and the appellant was partitioned but no boundary marks were erected on the line dividing the lands.

facts.text: In December 1960 there was a dispute between Rakkha Singh and the appellant and his brothers about the harvesting of sugarcane planted in the land.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1960 there was a dispute between Rakkha Singh on the one hand and the appellant and his brothers on the other about the harvesting of sugarcane planted in the land.

facts.text: Dispute settled on intervention of Sardar Ajit Singh; Rakkha Singh agreed to give seven hundred maunds of sugarcane to appellant and brothers.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute was settled on the intervention of one Sardar Ajit Singh, and Rakkha Singh agreed to give seven hundred maunds of sugarcane to the appellant and his brothers.

facts.text: On March 22, 1961, appellant and brothers went to house of Rakkha Singh and complained they were not given four hundred maunds out of seven hundred promised.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his brothers went to the house of Rakkha Singh on March 22, 1961 and complained that they were not given four hundred maunds of sugarcane out of the seven hundred maunds promised to them.

facts.text: Quarrel on March 22, 1961 between Karam Singh (eldest son of Rakkha Singh) and appellant; Karam Singh said appellant and brothers behaving like dishonest persons.

anchor.surface_text: There was a quarrel on that occasion between Karam Singh eldest son of Rakkha Singh and the appellant, the former saying that the appellant and his brothers were behaving like dishonest persons.

facts.text: On March 26, 1961 at about 6 p.m., Rakkha Singh, sons Karam Singh and Manjit Singh, and neighbour Sardar Anokh Singh were sitting in a thatched hut.

anchor.surface_text: On March 26, 1961 at about 6 p.m. when Rakkha Singh and his two sons Karam Singh and Manjit Singh and their neighbour Sardar Anokh Singh were sitting in a thatched hut,

facts.text: Appellant armed with gun and two brothers with lathis arrived near the hut; appellant shouted to Karam Singh to come out.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant armed with a gun, and his two brothers armed with lathis arrived near the hut, and the appellant shouted to Karam Singh asking him to come out of the hut.

facts.text: On Karam Singh emerging, appellant told him since he did not settle sugarcane dispute, he would settle his account, and opened fire causing chest injuries resulting in instantaneous death.

anchor.surface_text: On Karam Singhs emerging from the hut the appellant told him that since he  Karam Singh  did not settle the dispute regarding the sugarcane he would settle his account just then, and opened fire causing injuries to Karam Singh on the chest which resulted in death instantaneously.

facts.text: Rakkha Singh lodged first information at police station Puranpur at 7:45 a.m. on March 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Rakkha Singh then went to the police station Puranpur and lodged the first information at 7-45 a.m.

facts.text: Manjit Singh, Anokh Singh did not support prosecution case at trial; stated incident at 8 or 9 p.m., heard gunfire from houses, learned Karam Singh fired upon by masked Sardar.

anchor.surface_text: Manjit Singh and Anokh Singh however did not support the prosecution case. They stated that at about 8 or 9 p.m. on March 26, 1961 when they were in their respective houses they heard report of gun fire and on coming out came to learn from some person that Karam Singh was fired upon by some Sardar who was wearing a mask.

facts.text: Rakkha Singh supported prosecution case, including dispute, quarrel on March 22, and incident on March 26 at 6 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: But Rakkha Singh supported the prosecution case. He spoke about the dispute about sugarcane, and also about the quarrel between Karam Singh and the appellant on March 22, 1961.

facts.text: Rakkha Singh stated he could not see faces of assailants from hut but recognized them by gait and voice after coming out on hearing gunfire.

anchor.surface_text: In cross-examination he stated that from the hut in which he was sitting he could not see the faces of the assailants but on hearing the report of gun fire he came out of the hut and saw the assailants running away, and that he was able to recognise them by their gait and voice.

facts.text: Sessions Judge accepted testimony of Rakkha Singh inculpating appellant and convicted him; acquitted brothers.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions judge accepted the testimony of Rakkha Singh and, in so far as it inculpated the appellant, convicted him of the offence of causing the death of Karam Singh. He however held that the two brothers of the appellant were not proved to be guilty of the offence charged against them and acquitted them.

facts.text: High Court agreed with Sessions Judge findings and confirmed death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Allahabad agreed with the finding recorded by the Court of First Instance and confirmed the sentence of death passed against the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 10, 1963 by Shah J.

anchor.surface_text: P. Rana, for the appellant. C. Mathur and C. P. Lal, for the respondent. 1963. May 10. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH J.-

facts.text: Postmortem showed 8 ozs. of half-digested food in stomach of Karam Singh, indicating death two hours after last meal.

anchor.surface_text: The postmortem examination of the stomach contents of Karam Singh disclosed that there was 8 ozs. of half-digested food and that indicated that the death was caused some two hours after the last meal was taken by Karam Singh

facts.text: Rakkha Singh deposed Karam Singh took tea and pakodas at about 4 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: but Rakkha Singh has deposed that Karam Singh had taken at about 4 p.m. tea and pakadas.

facts.text: Distance between Shanti Nagar and Puranpur police station about 15 miles as crow flies, longer by public transport.

anchor.surface_text: The distance between the police station and the village Shanti Nagar, as the crow flies, is about 15 miles but by the public transport system one has to take a long detour to reach Puranpur Police Station.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirmed conviction and death sentence of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of the appellant must therefore be confirmed. Sentence passed by the Trial Court is, in the circumstances of the case the only appropriate sentence.

concepts.unlisted_description: Exception to non-review of evidence in criminal appeals

issues.text: Whether the Supreme Court should review the evidence in this criminal appeal under Article 136, given that no question of law arises and normally evidence is not reviewed unless trial vitiated by illegality, irregularity, violation of natural justice, or gross miscarriage of justice?

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion recorded by the Court of First Instance and affirmed by the High Court is based upon appreciation of evidence and no question of law arises therefrom. Normally this Court does not proceed to review the evidence in appeals in criminal cases, unless the trial is vitiated by some illegality or irregularity of procedure or the trial is held in a manner violative of the rules of natural justice resulting in an unfair trial or unless the judgment under appeal has resulted

issues.text: Whether the conviction for murder can be sustained based on the testimony of a single witness who identified the appellant by voice and gait without seeing the assailant's face, given familiarity and circumstances?

anchor.surface_text: offence of murder. ... Rakkha Singh deposed that he had been able to recognise the appellant from his voice and gait. Rakkha Singh was the father-in-law of the appellant, and had during the last few days before the death of Karam Singh seen the appellant frequently. ... The case for the prosecution undoubtedly depends for its support upon the testimony of a single witness, who did not claim to have identified the assailant by seeing his face.

issues.text: Whether the committing Magistrate erred in committing the accused to Sessions Court without recording the evidence of witnesses to the actual commission of the offence under s. 207A CrPC, and what is the proper exercise of discretion thereunder?

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with the case, we think it necessary to observe that the committing Magistrate in this case erred in committing the accused to the Court of Session without recording the evidence of all the witnesses to the actual commission of the offence, Under the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by Act 26 of 1955, the Magistrate holding committal proceedings is required to take the evidence of such persons, if any, as may be produced by the prosecution as witnesses to the actual commission of the offence alleged, and if the Magistrate is of opinion that it is necessary in the interest of justice to take the evidence of any one or more of the other witnesses for the prosecution, he may take such evidence also s. 207A

arguments.claim: Supreme Court normally does not review evidence in criminal appeals unless trial vitiated by illegality, irregularity, violation of natural justice, or gross miscarriage of justice

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion recorded by the Court of First Instance and affirmed by the High Court is based upon appreciation of evidence and no question of law arises therefrom. Normally this Court does not proceed to review the evidence in appeals in criminal cases, unless the trial is vitiated by some illegality or irregularity of procedure or the trial is held in a manner violative of the rules of natural justice resulting in an unfair trial or unless the judgment under appeal has resulted

arguments.claim: No illegality, irregularity, natural justice violation, or gross miscarriage of justice warranting review of evidence

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the evidence about identification of a person by the timbre of his voice depending upon subtle variations in the overtones when the person recognising is not familiar with the person recognised may be somewhat risky in a criminal trial.

arguments.court_reasoning: Risky if not familiar, but here Rakkha intimately knew appellant, recent frequent meetings, heard voice referring to specific dispute

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule normally followed by Court allows conviction on reliable single witness; here sufficient daylight, intimate knowledge, heard dispute reference

arguments.claim: Rakkha Singh's testimony is credible and sufficient for conviction despite not seeing face

anchor.surface_text: Rakkha Singh deposed that he had been able to recognise the appellant from his voice and gait. Rakkha Singh was the father-in-law of the appellant, and had during the last few days before the death of Karam Singh seen the appellant frequently.

arguments.claim: Manjit Singh and Anokh Singh shielded appellant and their court testimony unreliable

anchor.surface_text: Manjit Singh and Anokh Singh have tried to shield the appellant by deposing that the assault took place at about 9 p.m. and that they were informed that the assailant had put on a mask. Their statements recorded in the course of investigation were inconsistent with the tenor of their evidence in Court.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions judge accepted the testimony of Rakkha Singh and, in so far as it inculpated the appellant, convicted him of the offence of causing the death of Karam Singh. He however held that the two brothers of the appellant were not proved to be guilty of the offence charged against them and acquitted them.

arguments.claim: Committing Magistrate erred by not recording evidence of eyewitnesses to offence under s.207A CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with the case, we think it necessary to observe that the committing Magistrate in this case erred in committing the accused to the Court of Session without recording the evidence of all the witnesses to the actual commission of the offence, Under the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by Act 26 of 1955, the Magistrate holding committal proceedings is required to take the evidence of such persons, if any, as may be produced by the prosecution as witnesses to the actual commission of the offence alleged, ... s. 207A

arguments.claim: Under s.207A, Magistrate must record eyewitness evidence and may record others if in interest of justice; normally examine principal witnesses in serious offences like murder

anchor.surface_text: if the Magistrate is of opinion that it is necessary in the interest of justice to take the evidence of any one or more of the other witnesses for the prosecution, he may take such evidence also s. 207A 4 . The Magistrate has in the enquiries relating to charges for serious offences like murder the power and indeed a duty in the interest of the accused, as well as in the larger interest of the public to record the evidence of other witnesses who throw light on the case.

arguments.claim: Sriram v State of Bombay does not support Magistrate guided solely by prosecutor in examining witnesses for serious offences

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the decision of this Court in Sriram The State of Bombay 1 , which may support the view that in the matter of examination of witnesses, especially in the inquiry relating to serious charges like murder and culpable homicide, the Magistrate is to be guided by the prosecutor.

arguments.claim: Magistrate must apply mind to s.173 documents and witness testimony to decide on further evidence

anchor.surface_text: He must apply his mind to the documents referred to in s. 173, and the testimony of witnesses, if any, produced by the prosecutor and examined, and consider whether in the interest of justice it is necessary to record the evidence of other witnesses.

holdings.text: The Supreme Court does not normally review evidence in criminal appeals under Article 136 unless the trial is vitiated by illegality, irregularity, violation of natural justice, or gross miscarriage of justice; here no such grounds exist warranting interference with lower courts' appreciation of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion recorded by the Court of First Instance and affirmed by the High Court is based upon appreciation of evidence and no question of law arises therefrom. Normally this Court does not proceed to review the evidence in appeals in criminal cases, unless the trial is vitiated by some illegality or irregularity of procedure or the trial is held in a manner violative of the rules of natural justice resulting in an unfair trial or unless the judgment under appeal has resulted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts' findings based on evidence appreciation; no question of law or procedural vitiation raised; no gross miscarriage.

holdings.text: Conviction for murder can be sustained on testimony of single reliable witness identifying by voice and gait without seeing face, given familiarity, recent interactions, and contextual shouts referring to specific dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Rakkha Singh deposed that he had been able to recognise the appellant from his voice and gait. Rakkha Singh was the father-in-law of the appellant, and had during the last few days before the death of Karam Singh seen the appellant frequently. ... The case for the prosecution undoubtedly depends for its support upon the testimony of a single witness, who did not claim to have identified the assailant by seeing his face.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rakkha intimately knew appellant; frequent recent meetings; heard voice prelude to shooting referencing dispute; sufficient daylight; lower courts accepted credibility after seeing witness.

holdings.text: The conviction and death sentence of Kirpal Singh for murder is confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of the appellant must therefore be confirmed. Sentence passed by the Trial Court is, in the circumstances of the case the only appropriate sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence appreciation by Sessions Judge and High Court correct; single witness reliable; defenses like delay, stomach contents, hostile witnesses rejected.

holdings.text: No gross delay in lodging FIR justifying doubt on prosecution story, considering distance to station, transport detour, lack of outpost authority, and use of jeep.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that there was some delay in lodging the first information, the offence took place according to Rakkha Singh at 6 p.m. ,on March 26, 1961 and information at the police station Puranpur was lodged at 7.45 a.m. on March 27, 1961. The distance between the police station and the village Shanti Nagar, as the crow flies, is about 15 miles but by the public transport system one has to take a long detour to reach Puranpur Police Station.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 15 miles direct but longer by road; outposts unauthorized; jeep procured promptly; no apprehension of violence.

holdings.text: Postmortem stomach contents consistent with 6 p.m. death, as explained by witness testimony of 4 p.m. light meal.

anchor.surface_text: The postmortem examination of the stomach contents of Karam Singh disclosed that there was 8 ozs. of half-digested food and that indicated that the death was caused some two hours after the last meal was taken by Karam Singh Counsel for the appellant said that the condition of the stomach supported the version of Manjit Singh and Anokh Singh, but Rakkha Singh has deposed that Karam Singh had taken at about 4 p.m. tea and pakodas.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Half-digested food aligns with 4 p.m. tea/pakodas two hours prior; rejects alternative timing from hostile witnesses.

holdings.text: Committing Magistrate erred in committing accused to Sessions without recording evidence of eyewitnesses to the offence under s.207A CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with the case, we think it necessary to observe that the committing Magistrate in this case erred in committing the accused to the Court of Session without recording the evidence of all the witnesses to the actual commission of the offence, Under the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by Act 26 of 1955, the Magistrate holding committal proceedings is required to take the evidence of such persons, if any, as may be produced by the prosecution as witnesses to the actual commission of the offence alleged,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory to record eyewitnesses produced; here failed to do so.

holdings.text: Under s.207A CrPC, Magistrate must mandatorily record evidence of prosecution eyewitnesses to offence; discretion to record others if necessary in interest of justice, considering gravity (e.g., murder), accused interests, public interest; normally examine principal witnesses in serious cases; must apply mind to s.173 documents and testimony, not guided solely by prosecutor.

anchor.surface_text: if the Magistrate is of opinion that it is necessary in the interest of justice to take the evidence of any one or more of the other witnesses for the prosecution, he may take such evidence also s. 207A 4 . The Magistrate has in the enquiries relating to charges for serious offences like murder the power and indeed a duty in the interest of the accused, as well as in the larger interest of the public to record the evidence of other witnesses who throw light on the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading; purposive (shorten delays but protect justice); distinguishes prior precedent; judicial discretion based on offence gravity, interests; normal rule for serious offences.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing in the decision of this Court in Sriram The State of Bombay  1 , which may support the view that in the matter of examination of witnesses, especially in the inquiry relating to serious charges like murder and culpable homicide, the Magistrate is to be guided by the prosecutor.

precedents.case_name: Sriram v. The State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Magistrate's duty in examination of witnesses during committal proceedings under s. 207A CrPC is not to be solely guided by the prosecutor

anchor.surface_text: Rakkha Singh deposed that he had been able to recognise the appellant from his voice and gait. Rakkha Singh was the father-in-law of the appellant, and had during the last few days before the death of Karam Singh seen the appellant frequently. ... The case for the prosecution undoubtedly depends for its support upon the testimony of a single witness, who did not claim to have identified the assailant by seeing his face.
The conviction of the appellant must therefore be confirmed. Sentence passed by the Trial Court is, in the circumstances of the case the only appropriate sentence.

anchor.surface_text: Before parting with the case, we think it necessary to observe that the committing Magistrate in this case erred in committing the accused to the Court of Session without recording the evidence of all the witnesses to the actual commission of the offence, Under the Code of Criminal Procedure as amended by Act 26 of 1955, the Magistrate holding committal proceedings is required to take the evidence of such persons, if any, as may be produced by the prosecution as witnesses to the actual commission of the offence alleged,
he companymitting Magistrate in this case erred in companymitting the accused to the Court of Session without recording the evidence of all the witnes

edges.explanation: Holding h7 elaborates the mandatory requirements under s.207A CrPC, addressing the issue i3 of whether the magistrate erred.

anchor.surface_text: if the Magistrate is of opinion that it is necessary in the interest of justice to take the evidence of any one or more of the other witnesses for the prosecution, he may take such evidence also s. 207A 4 . The Magistrate has in the enquiries relating to charges for serious offences like murder the power and indeed a duty in the interest of the accused, as well as in the larger interest of the public to record the evidence of other witnesses who throw light on the case.
